awd_titl_txt: SBE-UKRI: Collaborative Research: Centering Women of Color in STEM: Data-Driven Opportunities for Inclusion
awd_abstract_narration:
The economic prosperity of the United States relies on progress in science, the advancement of national health initiatives, and overall national prosperity in an increasingly technical economy. These advancements rely on a talented workforce with the ability to nimbly address new challenges and develop innovative technologies. Colleges and universities can best prepare this future workforce by ensuring that educational environments are effective for a diverse range of students. Women received only 20% of bachelor's degrees in physics and computer science between 2004-2014; Black women and Latinas earned only 2% of the physics degrees and 6% of computer science degrees. Math has similar rates: although 44% of bachelor's degrees were earned by women, only 6% were awarded to Black women and Latinas. The numbers are similar in the United Kingdom. This project is jointly funded with the UK's Economic and Social Research Council (ESRC) under the SBE-UKRI Lead Agency collaborative research opportunity.

This project will support institutions concerned with addressing this underrepresentation by creating a portal through which US and UK STEM departments can measure their success at graduating women (especially women of color) to that of comparable institutions and to their own prior performance. The portal will make use of sophisticated visualization tools and will be accessible and user-friendly. Users of this portal will include: STEM professors who want to contribute to progress in science by recruiting and supporting the most talented young scientific professionals of all backgrounds, and are in need of baseline information about their own institution as well as a way to measure their improvement over time; researchers in need of information to better understand the dynamics of underrepresentation and identify powerful practices for broadening participation; and students seeking out more effective places to study. The project will allow for identification of exemplary predominantly white, coeducational institutions, and to create opportunities for peer institutions to document their own progress towards inclusion. Since most women of color attend predominantly white institutions, this work has the potential to improve the postsecondary educational environment where the majority of these women work and learn. Improving the diversity of the scientific workforce has immediate benefits from science and also the prosperity of the nation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The participation of women in physics in the US and the UK is deeply limited; about 20% of the recipients of bachelor’s degrees in each country are women. The percent of those women who are Black, Latina or American Indian (in the US) and Black or minority ethnic (in the UK) is even smaller—almost vanishingly small. Furthermore, we have already shown, through the analysis of US physics graduation rates by institution, that in the US, women of color are likely to be isolated, scattered across many different institutions. Over 60 percent of the Black, Latina, American Indian and mixed-race women who received bachelor’s degrees in physics in the US between 2008 and 2017 did so at institutions where nine or fewer other women received similar degrees in the same time period; over 3/4ths were at institutions with 15 or fewer similar women (which is to say, one a year, on average).

Given how isolated these women are from others like them, and given the research findings that women of color tend to experience discouragement, isolation and microaggressions in physics settings, there is an urgent need to figure out what is already working, and what could work, to make physics departments more inclusive.

In this project, we created databases that allow access to these numbers. The US data set can be accessed geographically and also by user-chosen variables, including institution type (PhD-granting, masters-granting, liberal arts, other), population served (minority-serving vs predominantly White), women’s college or coed, and size. Users can specify their requirements and generate a list, for all institutions that meet their specifications, of the  proportion of women among physics grads (compared with their proportion in the overall college population); same for women of color; and same for Black, Latina and American Indian women. Users can also access lists of effective institutions along several dimensions, and could research specific institutions and compare them to similar institutions.

Very different data is available in the US and the UK. While the US data allowed us to drill down to the graduation data of particular institutions, the UK team was able to create a data set that is classified according to effectiveness scores (weighted averages based on the representation of Black and minority ethnic women among the student body and faculty, the rate at which Black and minority ethnic women are hired upon graduating, and the school’s Athena Swan standing). This data was available in two views, a geographic view and a list view. Because of laws around HESA data in the UK, we classified institutions into one of four categories: Top 10, above average, average and below average. 

The two datasets are accessible via a public website, which can be reached through two urls: http://women-of-color-in-stem.org/ and bame-women-in-stem.co.uk/.

Intellectual merit and broader impacts are intertwined in this project.  Public access to high-quality data supports rigorous, research-based efforts to broaden STEM participation among women, particularly women of color.  The need for this kind of data is clear, and has only increased since the onset of this project, demonstrating its Intellectual Merit.  

The Broader Impacts of this project arise from its utility in identifying physics departments with higher-than-expected graduation rates for women,  and providing access to data that supports departments as they seek to become more inclusive. This work has the potential to improve the postsecondary educational environment where women in physics work and learn.
